dph of rules wrote:

> I finally got the registered version yesterday. I can't hardly wait
> to go through all scenarios.
>
> I noticed a few interesting things so far (so I cheated to get extra
> money to find these interesting things):
>
> Why does an archer run after being close to lots of exploding bolts
> exploding? I had an archer up to 400 on everything but experience and
> his experience level was 40. I was launching lots of exploding bolts
> close to a wall and he started to run away on his own.

Explosions are the one thing that can hurt any member of your team,
regardless of who set them off.  Thieves can hurt themselves with their
own bombs if they're not careful, and accordingly, archers can hurt
themselves with their own exploding arrows.  Running away from an
explosion is the same reaction an enemy gets -- so you'll have to be
careful where you let those exploding bolts go off!

>
>
> Also, I had slime upto 180 on everything but experience (experience
> level was 20). When I left a scenario I had only 15 team members of
> my
>  team, most were slime), I got ready to purchase another team member
> and I couldn't. I checked the view of my team and behold, the number
> of slimes had surpassed 30!!

I guess slimes could be described as the brute force of a team.  If you
want to take out an enemy with sheer numbers as opposed to quality
characters, then you can hire some slimes the level before and let them
spend their time multiplying.  I don't usually use slimes because of the
way they divide, however, and how weak they are against some of the
more skilled opponents you'll encounter.

> Who can do the most damage in a single attack to a character: archer,
> cleric, mage, archmage, fire elemental, or druid?

Not reading up on the classes, I think it would have to be fire elemental.
Then I would assume archer, since they are the most warrior-like class,
and then druid, cleric, mage, archmage (archmages get even worse
bare-hand-damage than mages!).  You can check this out on your score
menu by examining damage/hit -- though each character of a similar
class does a different damage/hit, even if the stats are the same.

> I have a suggest new power for ghost: Possession. A ghost could
> possess the body of an ally or friend for a limited period of time
> and use the attacks of the possessed.  While the ghost is possessing,
>  all damage is inflicted upon the body of the possessed.  If the
> ghost
>  is possessing a druid, all faeries produced are on the side of the
> ghost.  If the ghost is possessing a cleric, all ghosts and skeletons
> produced are on the side of the ghost or the ghost could use the
> cleric's resurrection ability to create a new body (of character type
> chosen by the ghost) for the ghost.

Kind of like the mage's hypnosis and the thief's charm, only the ghost
is temporarily removed from the battlefield?  It would have to be
fairly high-level--consider a ghost on the opposing team taking one of
your "giant" characters.

-Chirs
